etymology.description: Two wings facing opposite directions; originally ‘wings’, later ‘leave; disobey’, then used as a phonetic loan for ‘not’.
etymology.interpretation: Depicts a pair of wings set in opposition. The sense shifted from a concrete image to the ideas of divergence or disobedience, and was later borrowed to express negation “not.” Often confused in shape with 韭, but unrelated.

examples.chinese: 这并非你的错(這並非你的錯)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè bìng fēi nǐ de cuò.

examples.chinese: 他的做法非法(他的做法非法)。
不要把是非颠倒(不要把是非顛倒)。
examples.english: Don’t turn right and wrong upside down.
